body.p: A teacher is experimenting with a new computer-based instruction and conducts a study to test its effectiveness. In which situation could the teacher use a hypothesis test for matched pairs?

input.choice: The teacher gives each student in the class a pretest. Then she teaches a lesson using a computer program. Afterwards, she gives each student a post-test. The teacher wants to see if the difference in scores will show an improvement.

The teacher randomly divides the class into two groups. One of the groups receives computer-based instruction. The other group receives traditional instruction without computers. After instruction, each student takes a test and the teacher wants to compare the performance of the two groups.

The teacher uses a combination of traditional methods and computer-based instruction. She asks students which they liked better. She wants to determine if the majority prefer the computer-based instruction.

response.feedback: Correct. Since the same group of students was measured twice (once before and then after instruction) this is a case of matched pairs design.
Incorrect. Since students were randomized to two different groups the data obtained from this study should be analyzed using the two (independent) samples t-test.
Incorrect. The teachers collects data on the variable: “liked computer-based instruction better” (yes/no). With this data the teacher could test a hypothesis about a proportion.

body.p: A researcher wants to determine whether shoppers will spend more money at the grocery when they use a credit card to pay for their groceries rather than cash. In which situation could the researcher use a hypothesis test for matched pairs?

input.choice: The people in the experiment are told to use only cash for their grocery shopping for one trip and report how much money they spent. The next trip, the same people in the sample use only credit cards for their grocery shopping and calculate the total. The researcher compares the total spent by each individual to see if they spent more, on average, when using cash or the credit card.

The researcher randomly assigns half of the sample to only use cash for their grocery shopping for one trip to the grocery store. The other half of the sample uses only credit cards. The researcher compares the amount of money spent by each of the two groups.
The researcher asks the people in the sample whether they prefer to shop for their groceries using a credit card more than with cash (yes/no).

response.feedback: Correct. Since the same group of shoppers was measured twice (once with cash and then once with a credit card) this is a case of matched pairs design.
Incorrect. Since shoppers were randomly assigned to two different groups the data obtained from this study should be analyzed using the two (independent) samples t test.
Incorrect. The researchers collects data on the variable: “liked credit cards better” (yes/no). With this data the researcher could test a hypothesis about a proportion.

body.p: In which of the following situations would it be appropriate to use a paired t-test to analyze the data? Check all that apply.

input.choice: A marriage therapist believes that many couples have different perspectives regarding the state of their marriage prior to the start of couples therapy. In order to determine whether there is difference in marital satisfaction, prior to the start of couples therapy, each member of 30 married couples is individually given a marital satisfaction questionnaire. For each couple, the marital satisfaction scores of the wife and husband are compared to see if there is a difference in how they view the state of their marriage.

A psychologist was interested in determining whether fraternal twins differ in terms the degree to which they are extroverts. A sample of 50 fraternal twins was given the Eysenck personality questionnaire to assess their levels of extraversion. Each twin’s extraversion score was compared to his/her fraternal twin.

A psychiatrist believes that a new medication (New Drug) is more effective at reducing the symptoms of depression than a placebo, sugar pill (Placebo). Sixty people with depression were randomly assigned to one of two groups, (1) New Drug or (2) Placebo, and were given the assigned drug or sugar pill for 30 days. Each of the 60 participants then completed the Beck Depression Inventory and the mean depression score for the New Drug group is compared to the mean depression score for the Placebo group.

A researcher is interested in determining the effects of sleep deprivation on the accuracy with which mazes are completed. Thirty people are given a test of mazes on Day 1 at 9 am and again on Day 2 at 9 pm after being kept awake for 36 hours. The researcher then compares the number of errors made on Day 1 to Day 2.

response.feedback: Incorrect. You are correct that since the marital satisfaction study uses marital couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the extroversion study uses fraternal twins, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. Individuals in the depression drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the sleep deprivation study uses the same participants for both a pretest measure (Day 1) and a post-test measure (Day 2), the observations in one sample are dependent on the observations in another sample; therefore, the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the marital satisfaction study uses marital couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Additionally, you are correct that since the extroversion study uses fraternal twins, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the marital satisfaction study uses marital couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, individuals in the depression drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test. Additionally, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the marital satisfaction study uses marital couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Additionally, you are correct that since the sleep deprivation study uses the same participants for both a pretest measure (Day 1) and a posttest measure (Day 2), the observations in one sample are dependent on the observations in another sample; therefore, the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the extroversion study uses fraternal twins, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, individuals in the depression drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test. Additionally, there is at least one other correct answer.

Additionally, you are correct that since the sleep deprivation study uses the same participants for both a pretest measure (Day 1) and a post-test measure (Day 2), the observations in one sample are dependent on the observations in another sample; therefore, the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the sleep deprivation study uses the same participants for both a pretest measure (Day 1) and a post-test measure (Day 2), the observations in one sample are dependent on the observations in another sample; therefore, the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, individuals in the depression drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test. Additionally, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the marital satisfaction study uses marital couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Additionally, you are correct that since the extroversion study uses fraternal twins, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, individuals in the depression drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test.

Correct. Since the marital satisfaction study uses marital couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Additionally, since the extroversion study uses fraternal twins, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Lastly, since the sleep deprivation study uses the same participants for both a pretest measure (Day 1) and a post-test measure (Day 2), the observations in one sample are dependent on the observations in another sample; therefore, the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the marital satisfaction study uses marital couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Additionally, you are correct that since the sleep deprivation study uses the same participants for both a pretest measure (Day 1) and a post-test measure (Day 2), the observations in one sample are dependent on the observations in another sample; therefore, the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, individuals in the depression drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the extroversion study uses fraternal twins, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Additionally, you are correct that since the sleep deprivation study uses the same participants for both a pretest measure (Day 1) and a post-test measure (Day 2), the observations in one sample are dependent on the observations in another sample; therefore, the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, individuals in the depression drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the marital satisfaction study uses marital couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Additionally, you are correct that since the extroversion study uses fraternal twins, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Furthermore, you are correct that since the sleep deprivation study uses the same participants for both a pretest measure (Day 1) and a posttest measure (Day 2), the observations in one sample are dependent on the observations in another sample; therefore, the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, individuals in the depression drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test.
Incorrect. There is at least one correct answer.

body.p: In which of the following situations would it be appropriate to use a paired t-test to analyze the data? Check all that apply.

input.choice: A researcher was interested in the differences in attitudes towards saving money and eliminating debt between couples who are engaged to be married. As part of a premarital counseling program, 45 engaged couples filled out a survey that assessed their attitudes towards financial matters such as their priorities for saving money and eliminating debt. The researcher compared the scores of each member of the engaged couple to see if there was a mean difference in the couples’ attitudes towards saving money and eliminating debt.

A biologist was interested in finding out whether rats who are littermates (siblings who are born at the same time) have similar abilities when learning how to run a maze. The biologists selected 50 pairs of littermates and tested how many trials it took for the rat to get to the end of the maze in less than 10 seconds. The null hypothesis was that there would be no mean difference in the number of trials that the rat and their litter mate would take to complete the maze in under 10 seconds. Each rat’s maze time was compared to his/her littermate.

A medical researcher believes that a new drug will increase a patient’s red blood cell count at a higher rate than that achieved by an old drug currently in use. The researcher randomly assigns 50 patients to be in the “new drug” group and 50 patients to be in the “old drug” group, then compares the mean red blood cell count for the “new drug” group to the red blood cell count of the “old drug” group.

A researcher is interested in determining the effects of caffeine on manual dexterity. The researcher recruits a sample of 60 participants and asks each participant to complete a manual dexterity task similar to the game “Operation.” Each participant completes the task twice: On Day 1, participants complete the task when they have not consumed any caffeine for at least 6 hours. On Day 2, the participants drink a beverage with 200 mg of caffeine 20 minutes before completing the task. The researcher compares each individual’s number of errors in the task with and without caffeine exposure and computes a mean difference.

response.feedback: Incorrect. You are correct that since the financial attitudes study uses engaged couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the maze ability study uses littermates, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. Individuals in the red blood cell drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test. Additionally, there is at least one correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the caffeine study uses the same participants for both a pretest measure (Day 1) and a posttest measure (Day 2), the observations in one sample are dependent on the observations in another sample; therefore, the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the financial attitudes study uses engaged couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. Additionally, you are correct that since the maze ability study uses littermates, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, there is at least one other correct answer.

Incorrect. You are correct that since the financial attitudes study uses engaged couples, which are a “natural pair,” the appropriate statistical technique would be the paired t-test. However, individuals in the red blood cell drug study are randomly assigned to two groups are not matched; therefore, the observations in one sample are not linked to another sample. The correct statistical technique for this study would be the two independent samples t-test. Additionally, there is at least one other correct answer.
